title: For Sale:  Colt Early Post-War and  Model .45 W/ Military Surplus Parts...C220810...Mfd 1946...No Reserve .45 ACP
postcontent:
NO RESERVE!! Here's an interesting and fairly scarce Colt pistol. This is an early post-war Colt Government Model .45 automatic. This pistol is among the very first Government Models made following the end of World War Two and exhibits some interesting features not found on any other Colt .45. The very first post-war .45 was serial number C220001...this is serial number C220810.
Always fiscally conscious, Colt seldom disposed of workable parts. Colt had many slides, barrels and other military components left over from war-time 1911A1 production. These parts were worked into commercial production as a cost saving measure. Only the earliest post-war commercial pistols are found with these military components. This pistol has the war-time slide which is rollmarked in the military style on the left but also in the commercial fashion on the right...the Colt "prancing pony" appears on both sides! The rollmarkings are slightly faint, which is normal even on an original finish pistol. The hammer, slide stop, safety, mainspring housing w/ lanyard loop, and stamped trigger are military as well. The grips are likewise WWII Colt plastic. The barrel is correct late WWII production marked "COLT 45 AUTO" beneath the chamber with a small "F" in front of the lugs. The top of the barrel chamber is polished "in the white" as was customary on commercial pistols. This pistol is in very good overall condition although it does show some normal finish wear from use. The finish on the slide shows a bit more thinning than does the frame and there are some handling marks and various fine scratches scattered about. There are a few tiny freckles here and there but nothing significant and no pitting. The frame's feed ramp is correctly milled "in the white", a good indicator of original finish. Internal wear patterns are consistent between frame/barrel/slide and they appear to be original to one another. The grips are in excellent shape, free of cracks or chips. The mechanics appear to be in good working order and the bore is excellent with bright, sharp rifling. It comes with a WWII "Scoville Mfg Co" contract magazine. This hard to find Colt .45 variation can be found in the serial range C220001-C222000 and was made between October, 1946-January 1947.
